text:
This  report  details  exploration  carried  out  on  Wallbrook  tenement  E31/478  during  the 
 reporting period 17/02/2005 to 16/02/2006. Jackson Gold is the beneficial and/or registered 
 holder of the tenements. 
 Tenement  E31/478  is  located  on  the  Edjudina  Station,  approximately  130  km  NE  from 
 Kalgoorlie. The project area is situated in the Eastern Goldfields of Western Australia within 
 the  North  Coolgardie  Mineral  Fields’  Yerilla  District.  Access  to  the  project  area  is  via  the 
 Kalgoorlie – Kurnalpi – Pinjin road as far as the Carosue mine site access road and then via 
 station tracks (Figure 1.). 
 The Wallbrook Project area lies in the Pinjin Belt, in the eastern part of the Norseman – 
 Wiluna greenstone belt in the Eastern Goldfields Province of the Archaean Yilgarn Craton. 
 The stratigraphy underlying tenement E31/478 comprises basalt and andesites. The sequence 
 is  intruded  by  late-stage  granitoids  with  stopped  and  sheared  contacts.  The  Galvally 
 Monzogranite has been interpreted from the aeromagnetic data to underlay the southern and 
 eastern areas of the tenement. 
 Jackson Gold Ltd entered into an Option Agreement with Croesus Mining Ltd in May 2002 to 
 acquire Croesus’ 75% of the Wallbrook Project upon raising $3.5 million and attaining listing 
 on the ASX. In July 2002, Jackson Gold negotiated the purchase of the remaining 25% of the 
 the  minor  equity  holders,  being  Synergy  Metals  Ltd  and  Supersorb 
 Environmental Ltd, at a total consideration of $65,000 cash and 275,000 fully paid Jackson 
 Gold shares. Exploration licence 31/478 was granted on the 17th February 2004.  
 Exploration  activities  included  regolith  mapping,  geochemical  data  processing  and  auger 
 sampling (Figure 2.).

43.text: Region in the Laverton Tectonic Zone, centrally between Kalgoorlie and Laverton.

 The Wallbrook Project occurs within the Norseman - Wiluna Archaean Greenstone belt in the 
 Eastern Goldfields province of the Yilgarn Craton. The Project is located within the Edjudina 
 Region in the Laverton Tectonic Zone, centrally between Kalgoorlie and Laverton. 
 The granite-greenstone belt is approximately 600 kilometres in length, and is characterised by 
 thick, possibly rift-controlled, accumulations of ultramafic, mafic, felsic volcanic, intrusives 
 and sedimentary rocks.  Greenstone successions of the southern Eastern Goldfields have been 
 segregated  into  elongate  structural  terranes  bounded  by  regional  NNW-trending  faults 
 (Swager, 1995).  These terranes include the Kalgoorlie Terrane, Gindalbie Terrane, Kurnalpi 
 Terrane and the Edjudina Terrane. These terrains contain distinct similarities, including timing 
 of the deposition of volcano-sedimentary sequences (2720-2675 Ma) and regional deformation 
 and plutonism (2675-2620 Ma). The terrains differ only in lithostratigraphic development and 
 early tectonic history (Swager, 1995). 
 The Edjudina Terrane is bounded by the Claypan Fault and the Pinjin Fault. The Terrane is 
 dominated by calc-alkaline, andesitic volcanic complexes and their epiclastic debris with only

4.text: Monzogranite has been interpreted from the aeromagnetic data to underlay the southern and

5.text: eastern  areas  of  the  tenement  (Figure  3.).  The  metamorphic  grade  is  typically  greenschist

6.text: facies. In the northern part of the tenement thermal metamorphism caused by the intrusion of a

7.text: late stage granite has altered the mafics to amphibolite schists. The area is structurally located

8.text: between the Claypan Fault in the east and the Keith – Kilkenny Fault Zone in the west with

9.text: secondary faulting derived from these major structures.

text:
Monzogranite has been interpreted from the aeromagnetic data to underlay the southern and 
 eastern  areas  of  the  tenement  (Figure  3.).  The  metamorphic  grade  is  typically  greenschist 
 facies. In the northern part of the tenement thermal metamorphism caused by the intrusion of a 
 late stage granite has altered the mafics to amphibolite schists. The area is structurally located 
 between the Claypan Fault in the east and the Keith – Kilkenny Fault Zone in the west with 
 secondary faulting derived from these major structures.

12.text: Known gold mineralisation in the region is commonly associated with felsic host rocks, such

13.text: as sheared, ductile and brittle deformed quartz – feldspar porphyries and dacitic to rhyolitic

14.text: metavolcanics.  Regionally  gold  has  been  produced  from  the  Mulgabbie  Mining  Centre,  the

15.text: Carosue Dam Group and the Wallbrook area.

17.text: A number of old workings occur adjacent to the contact at Mulgabbie within the sediments,

18.text: and two sets of workings occur further southwest within the major shear zone. These workings

19.text: follow  mineralised  quartz  veins  at  high  angles  to  the  bedding  and  schistosity.  The  shear  is

20.text: locally  mineralised  where  the  felsic  rocks  have  been  altered  into  Quartz-sericite  schist  +/-

21.text: chlorite +/- carbonate. Significant gold appears to be associated with quartz veining.

23.text: The main mineralised trend in the Carosue Dam Group of deposits extends for approximately

24.text: 20  strike  kilometres  and  consists  of  a  sequence  of  felsic  to  intermediate  volcanic,

25.text: volcanoclastic  and  epiclastic  rocks  with  minor  intrusives  which  strike  approximately

26.text: northwest  and  have  moderate  northeasterly  dips  (Langworthy,  1999).  The  three  resources,

27.text: Karari, Whirling Dervish and Luvironza are concealed by 8 – 30 metres of transported cover,

28.text: comprising colluvium-alluvium and lacustrine clays and quartz sand. Beneath the transported

29.text: cover, variably stripped strongly gold-depleted saprolite occurs to vertical depths ranging from

30.text: 10 – 60 metres. Gold mineralisation is largely confined to the volcaniclastics and is associated

31.text: with  highly  visible  albite,  K-feldspar,  silica,  heamatite,  carbonate,  and  pyrite  alteration

32.text: assemblages.  Quartz  veining  is  largely  restricted  to  fine-scale  stock  works.  Mineralised

text:
Known gold mineralisation in the region is commonly associated with felsic host rocks, such 
 as sheared, ductile and brittle deformed quartz – feldspar porphyries and dacitic to rhyolitic 
 metavolcanics.  Regionally  gold  has  been  produced  from  the  Mulgabbie  Mining  Centre,  the 
 Carosue Dam Group and the Wallbrook area. 
 A number of old workings occur adjacent to the contact at Mulgabbie within the sediments, 
 and two sets of workings occur further southwest within the major shear zone. These workings 
 follow  mineralised  quartz  veins  at  high  angles  to  the  bedding  and  schistosity.  The  shear  is 
 locally  mineralised  where  the  felsic  rocks  have  been  altered  into  Quartz-sericite  schist  +/- 
 chlorite +/- carbonate. Significant gold appears to be associated with quartz veining. 
 The main mineralised trend in the Carosue Dam Group of deposits extends for approximately 
 20  strike  kilometres  and  consists  of  a  sequence  of  felsic  to  intermediate  volcanic, 
 volcanoclastic  and  epiclastic  rocks  with  minor  intrusives  which  strike  approximately 
 northwest  and  have  moderate  northeasterly  dips  (Langworthy,  1999).  The  three  resources, 
 Karari, Whirling Dervish and Luvironza are concealed by 8 – 30 metres of transported cover, 
 comprising colluvium-alluvium and lacustrine clays and quartz sand. Beneath the transported 
 cover, variably stripped strongly gold-depleted saprolite occurs to vertical depths ranging from 
 10 – 60 metres. Gold mineralisation is largely confined to the volcaniclastics and is associated 
 with  highly  visible  albite,  K-feldspar,  silica,  heamatite,  carbonate,  and  pyrite  alteration 
 assemblages.  Quartz  veining  is  largely  restricted  to  fine-scale  stock  works.  Mineralised

33.text: structures  have  two  distinct  orientations.  The  first  set  of  lobe  structures  strike  dominantly

34.text: parallel to stratigraphy and is associated with alteration dominated by silica-albite-pyrite. The

35.text: second  set  of  load  structures  are  characterised  by  flat  to  shallow  west  dipping  zones  of

36.text: tensional  quartz  veining  and  brecciation,  associated  with  strong  haematite-carbonate-pyrite

37.text: alteration. These observations are consistent whereby mineralisation occurs in steeply dipping

38.text: reverse ductile shear zones, with shallower-dipping, more tensional links between them.

text:
structures  have  two  distinct  orientations.  The  first  set  of  lobe  structures  strike  dominantly 
 parallel to stratigraphy and is associated with alteration dominated by silica-albite-pyrite. The 
 second  set  of  load  structures  are  characterised  by  flat  to  shallow  west  dipping  zones  of 
 tensional  quartz  veining  and  brecciation,  associated  with  strong  haematite-carbonate-pyrite 
 alteration. These observations are consistent whereby mineralisation occurs in steeply dipping 
 reverse ductile shear zones, with shallower-dipping, more tensional links between them.

40.text: Competency  contrast  is  considered  important  in  localising  mineralised  vein  systems  at  the

41.text: Wallbrook  deposit  (Roberts,  F.I  et  al,  2000).  At  Wallbrook  a  mineralised  quartz  vein

42.text: stockwork has developed within a small syenogranitic intrusion within metabasalt.

45.text: The southern portion of the tenement area is underlain by the Lake Rebecca salt lake system.

46.text: The remainder of the area is predominantly overlain by extensive sheet wash derived from the

47.text: adjacent granite.  The regolith is shown in the Landsat TM image which is presented in Figure

text:
Competency  contrast  is  considered  important  in  localising  mineralised  vein  systems  at  the 
 Wallbrook  deposit  (Roberts,  F.I  et  al,  2000).  At  Wallbrook  a  mineralised  quartz  vein 
 stockwork has developed within a small syenogranitic intrusion within metabasalt.  
 The southern portion of the tenement area is underlain by the Lake Rebecca salt lake system. 
 The remainder of the area is predominantly overlain by extensive sheet wash derived from the 
 adjacent granite.  The regolith is shown in the Landsat TM image which is presented in Figure

3.text: It  is  evident  from  the  regional  aeromagnetic  data  that  the  majority  of  the  project  area  is

4.text: underlain  by  the  Galvalley  Monzogranite  (Figure  5.)  Granitoids,  including  the  Galvally

5.text: Monzogranite,  emplaced  prior  to  regional  folding  occur  as  sheets  which  are  generally

6.text: conformable with overall greenstone layering. A major north-west to north-northwest trending

text:
It  is  evident  from  the  regional  aeromagnetic  data  that  the  majority  of  the  project  area  is 
 underlain  by  the  Galvalley  Monzogranite  (Figure  5.)  Granitoids,  including  the  Galvally 
 Monzogranite,  emplaced  prior  to  regional  folding  occur  as  sheets  which  are  generally 
 conformable with overall greenstone layering. A major north-west to north-northwest trending 
 structure transects the project area.

 9049 
 Edjudina Gold Project – Hobble Gap 
 Goldfields Exploration Pty Ltd 
 1993- 1996 
 Goldfield’s  Hobble  Gap  project  covered  a  large  package  of  ground  including  the  extreme 
 northern  margin  of  tenement  E31/478.  Exploration  activities  included  interpretation  of 
 aeromagnetic  data,  geological  mapping,  as  well  as  auger  soil  sampling  and  RAB  drilling, 
 which did not fall within the boundaries of E31/478. 
 Kingsley Project 
 Companies  Westerm mining Corporation 
 Talon Resources NL 
 1994- 1998 
 The Kingsley Project covered an area which included the current area of tenement E31/478. 
 During the period 1994 to 1997, WMC exploration activities included regional geological and 
 regolith mapping, a regional gravity survey, an induced polarisation survey, an aeromagnetic 
 and radiometric survey, soil sampling and reconnaissance aircore drilling. A total of 30 aircore 
 holes were drilled in the northern half of E31/478.  In 1997 the Kingsely Project was divested 
 by WMC to Talon Resources.   
 During the period 1997 to 1998, Talon Resources conducted a structural study in an attempt to 
 identify structurally controlled mineralisation similar to the Wallbrook deposit.

text:
5.2 Geochemical Data Processing  
 Statistical  levelling  of  the  gold  from  the  surface  geochemical  database  which  includes  both  
 historical  and  recent  sampling  conducted  by  Jackson  Gold  for  the  Wallbrook  Project  area, 
 including the northern third of E31/478, has been conducted by Jonno King during the 2005 
 work  year.  The  geochemical  data  set  comprises  numerous  discrete  surveys  or  batches,  the

16.text: presence  of  differing  backgrounds  and  thresholds  commonly  causes  ‘edge  effects’  that  can

17.text: obscure  real  data  trends.  Levelling  involves  a  statistical  manipulation  of  the  data  so  as  to

18.text: minimize  batch  effects  which  include  different  sample  media,  sampling  methods,  digestion

19.text: and analytical techniques and laboratory batch results. Levelling of the data generated several

20.text: new  trends  and  anomalies  and  in  some  case  a  better  –  constrained  existing  anomalies.  The

21.text: levelled gold geochemistry data is presented in Figure 7.

26.text: A pedogenic carbonate auger drilling programme comprising 156 holes was conducted during

27.text: the reporting period. The auger holes were drilled over the northern half of E31/478 on a 300

28.text: m by 150 m grid. Drillhole locations are presented in Figure 8.  Digital data for the drilling

29.text: programme including hole collars and assays is presented in Appendix 1.

31.text: The  samples  were  submitted  to  Amdel  Laboratories  for  the  analysis  of  Au  (1ppb),  As

32.text: (0.5ppm),  Bi  (0.1ppm),  Ca  (10ppm),  Fe  (100ppm), Mn (5ppm), Mo (0.1ppm), Pb (0.2ppm)

33.text: and Sb (0.1 ppm) using an aqua regia digest and an atomic absorption spectroscopy finish.

text:
presence  of  differing  backgrounds  and  thresholds  commonly  causes  ‘edge  effects’  that  can 
 obscure  real  data  trends.  Levelling  involves  a  statistical  manipulation  of  the  data  so  as  to 
 minimize  batch  effects  which  include  different  sample  media,  sampling  methods,  digestion 
 and analytical techniques and laboratory batch results. Levelling of the data generated several 
 new  trends  and  anomalies  and  in  some  case  a  better  –  constrained  existing  anomalies.  The 
 levelled gold geochemistry data is presented in Figure 7. 
 A pedogenic carbonate auger drilling programme comprising 156 holes was conducted during 
 the reporting period. The auger holes were drilled over the northern half of E31/478 on a 300 
 m by 150 m grid. Drillhole locations are presented in Figure 8.  Digital data for the drilling 
 programme including hole collars and assays is presented in Appendix 1.  
 The  samples  were  submitted  to  Amdel  Laboratories  for  the  analysis  of  Au  (1ppb),  As 
 (0.5ppm),  Bi  (0.1ppm),  Ca  (10ppm),  Fe  (100ppm), Mn (5ppm), Mo (0.1ppm), Pb (0.2ppm) 
 and Sb (0.1 ppm) using an aqua regia digest and an atomic absorption spectroscopy finish.

4.text: Regolith mapping was conducted over Jackson Gold’s Wallbrook Project including   the north

5.text: western portion of tenement E31/478. The mapping was undertaken at a scale of 1: 25 000 by

6.text: consultant Jonno King. The mapping has been digitally captured and is presented in Figure 6.

7.text: This  landform  interpretation  exercise  was  conducted  over  the  project  area  with  a  view  to

8.text: normalising the surface geochemistry and generating exploration targets
